body: This PR aims to create a new file kind for INLINE stuffs as requested by @iphydf in #519. Enjoy. :) > This file kind is aimed for clients to implement inline features such as : > Stickers, inline images, inline videoclips, inline music, and so on. --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/744)

comment_regular_data.body: I like the idea of inline media. Would this still default to manual accept, or would auto-accept be an appropriate default? Currently [the TCS](https://tox.gitbooks.io/tox-client-standard/content/communication/file_transfers.html) says that all file transfers should be manually accepted by default, which IMO decreases ease of use for inline media for qTox which already does this for recognized image formats on file transfers. On the other hand, auto-accept by default also increases attack surface through exploitation of media formats or network/storage exhaustion, so I understand the motivation. If auto-accept is appropriate for inline, is there still an argument for it being prohibited by default in the TCS for non-inline media? It seems like what ever the argument is for one, it could be made for the other, and either both should be able to be auto-accept by default or both should not.

I guess it should be enabled by default. The point is that: video should displays a preview, and only let the user wether it decides to play it or not, same for music files that are inlined. As GIF that only should animate when the user hover's it, both for privacy/performances reasons.

--- Reviewed 2 of 2 files at r1. Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, all discussions resolved. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/744#-:-L4BOmTmQcsusmI9-5tA:b-jbsf8z)*

does this actually make sense? the client decides what it shows inline and what not, regardless of this type.
images are shown inline already by most clients.

stickers would actually mean a different **message** type. like "Rich text Message" or "Markup Message"

all i can see here is an AUTO_ACCEPT file transfer. and incompatibility with older clients.
@SkyzohKey do you have a screenshot, or a mockup of what this should look like, in contrast to a regular filetransfer?
I don't care at all, so I'll leave this up to you two (@zoff99, @SkyzohKey) to discuss.

@zoff99 Yep => 

### Inline image + message + mp3
![](https://mir-s3-cdn-cf.behance.net/project_modules/max_1200/6a3ea052007569.590326fe49790.png)

### Sticker
![](https://mir-s3-cdn-cf.behance.net/project_modules/max_1200/09ba4b52007569.590326fe49f57.png)

PS: I can make other mockups if that's needed

The main reason to want to implemented this is explained here: https://github.com/qTox/qTox/issues/402. It looks a regular file transfer would be enough for this. In this case it would have to be accepted automatically and the media would have to be played by pressing a button or on mouse hover. Can't just clients implement this for known file formats? I don't think it's a good idea to accept file transfers automatically by default though, but it's up to clients. I really don't like the idea that some unknown file might be sent to me without my permission.
@Diadlo I like that idea. Maybe the client should not remember the name of the file, but its hash?

@tox-user I suggest name beacuse it can be used to create sticker packs. For example:
Cats pack:
cats_smile.png
cats_sad.png
cats_smile2.png

Memes pack:
memes_pain_harold.png
memes_if_you_know_what_i_mean.png

@Diadlo @tox-user can you have a look at #735 
it will solve a lot of these issues.

like:
* double message sending
* correction message
* multipart messages
* out of order message
i still can not see the difference between a "sticker" and a normal filetransfer image
Is not relying on a hack to display an inline image or a sticker not a difference? Tox has built-in file kinds, that's by design and I wonder why it didn't got added first
Can you rebase this?
Yes, we need to add that to apidsl. That's separate from this PR, though. We can add this enumerator now and add explicit values later.
@SkyzohKey please rebase.

@iphydf there is no "inline" thing in toxcore. can you explain to me what this should do?
how should this even work in the real world?

now one client just decides what is inline and what is not? and what should the receiving client do with this information?
also what happens when client A sends a 10Gbyte movie file as "inline" ? should this now be autoaccept?
also what happens when client A sends an Excel file as "inline" ?
what if the receiving client does not have a display or a very small screen?

for toxcore there is NO file type and there can't be.

I don't get it either. This isn't a new kind of file. This is just an image or some other existing type of file that will be autoaccepted by a client and displayed differently from other files (assuming a client wants to do that). Some clients already implement this - they autoaccept certain files. If you want to have that functionality in your client just accept all files or restrict it to files with certain names, extensions, size or whatever you prefer.

The file kind is a hint to the receiver what the intended use of the sent file is. The receiver can do with that as they wish. If someone sends a 10gb image as inline, then the receiving client can reject, ask the user, or take any other action it deems appropriate.
If it's up to the receiver to decide, we don't need to add this to toxcore. They can already do all of that.
Yes, it's the same as for avatars. It's a contract between clients that isn't part of toxcore's behaviour. Should we remove the file type enum altogether?

@iphy 3 things:
1) not all clients will have implemented this new type. what happens if this type of file is sent to an old client? (no capabilities feature yet)
2) "hint" should be just as u suggest, a hint. not a new file type. (filetransferV2 with metadata?)
3) avatar type is already implemented in (mostly?) all clients. so keep that
Most client authors seem to think this is not useful. Other client authors are still free to add their own file kinds (which is why it's an int, not an enum).

title: Create TOX_FILE_KIND_INLINE
